This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-04-10 18:30:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/36490). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

On August 16, 2022, President Joe Biden signed into law the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which established the Advanced Manufacturing Production Tax Credit (AMPTC) for the domestic production of specific clean energy components.

In the wake of the 2024 US elections, Republicans took control of both Houses of Congress and the White House, with President Donald Trump [having expressed interest](https://www.brookings.edu/articles/what-will-happen-to-the-inflation-reduction-act-under-a-republican-trifecta/#the-ira-under-the-incoming-republican-white-house-and-congress) in reducing IRA spending. At the time of this question, congressional Republicans were working on a budget reconciliation bill to possibly enact tax and spending changes to the federal budget (see the Tax Foundation's updated [Budget Reconciliation tracker](https://taxfoundation.org/research/all/federal/trump-tax-cuts-2025-budget-reconciliation/)).

It is important to note that in the House of Representatives, the Republicans hold a slim majority of 220 to 213. In March 2025, a group of 21 Republican representatives [sent a letter](https://www.eenews.net/articles/republicans-mull-thoughtful-phaseout-of-green-credits/) to House Ways and Means Chairman Jason Smith to urge him to phase out rather than eliminate the clean energy incentives of the IRA. House Speaker Mike Johnson [told reporters](https://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/5167829-johnson-inflation-reduction-act-ira-climate-tax-infrastructure/), in regard to repealing clean energy tax credits among other policies, "It’ll be somewhere between a scalpel and a sledgehammer." It's important to note, too, that reconciliation bills do not always succeed. In July 2017, for example, Senator John McCain famously [cast](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/27/us/politics/senate-health-care-vote.html) a decisive No vote to a reconciliation bill that would have repealed parts of the Affordable Care Act.

**API now opposes year-round E15 sales, citing shifting, unstable environment for refiners**
The American Petroleum Institute (API) has reversed its previous stance and now opposes the Nationwide Consumer and Fuel Retailer Choice Act of 2025, which would allow year-round sales of E15 gasoline (15% ethanol). In a letter to congressional leaders, API President Mike Sommers cited a dramatically changed operating environment for refiners and fuel blenders due to shifting federal compliance structures, a patchwork of state mandates, and an unstable biofuels marketplace. The legislation, co-sponsored by 16 senators—two each from Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, South Dakota, and West Virginia, and one each from Arizona, Mississippi, Nebraska, North Dakota, and Wisconsin—aims to amend the Clean Air Act to permit year-round E15 use, currently limited to part of the year. API member companies had invested in new infrastructure to produce region-specific E15 blends for eight Midwestern states that petitioned the EPA to opt out of the summer volatility waiver for E10. However, just days before delivery, the EPA issued emergency waivers that negated the opt-out requests, rendering the investments sunk costs and causing financial and operational harm. Additionally, the Big Beautiful Bill signed by President Donald Trump on July 4 eliminated Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Tax Credits for imported feedstocks from countries with lower carbon intensity, such as Brazil. Sommers emphasized that domestic feedstock is insufficient to meet U.S. biofuel production capacity, meaning foreign feedstocks remain essential for viable operations. API remains willing to work with Congress to develop a balanced E15 policy that supports fuel choice, investment certainty, and a stable marketplace for consumers.

**Trump’s budget bill is making energy expensive again**
According to a clean energy business leader writing for the Minnesota Reformer, President Donald Trump’s phaseout of clean energy tax credits—via the One Big Beautiful Bill Act—has triggered a rise in energy costs across the U.S. The repeal of these credits, which had supported hundreds of thousands of clean energy jobs since 2022, is projected to cost over 80,000 jobs and increase cumulative household energy expenses by $170 billion from 2025 to 2034, according to Energy Innovation. Since Trump took office, electricity prices have risen 10%, outpacing inflation, with nearly 60 utilities planning rate hikes affecting 56.7 million electric and 26 million gas customers. As of March, over $24 billion in late utility payments were owed. Despite solar, wind, and battery storage supplying over 90% of new U.S. energy capacity in 2024, the bill has stalled clean energy projects. The author criticizes Republican lawmakers for opposing the very policies that created 400,000 new clean energy jobs—most in Republican districts—calling the situation an 'avoidable energy crisis.' The author compares the repeal to cutting the rope of a climber just before rescue, stating that clean energy is now the cheapest energy globally and that government leadership must support it to lower bills, not exacerbate the crisis.

**‘Substantial’ layoffs of federal workers launched by Trump administration amid shutdown • NC Newsline**

The administration cited a 'bloated bureaucracy' under the Biden administration, with HHS spokesperson Andrew Nixon stating the workforce grew by 17% and the budget by 38%. DHS claimed CISA was previously misaligned with its mission. Unions, including the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE) and AFL-CIO, condemned the move as illegal and unprecedented, vowing legal challenges. AFGE President Everett Kelley emphasized no prior administration had fired furloughed workers during a shutdown. Judge Susan Illston ordered the administration to provide RIF details by end-of-day Friday. Senate Appropriations Chairwoman Susan Collins opposed the layoffs, warning of harm to public services and families. President Trump had previously threatened 'substantial' job losses if funding wasn't passed, and the stalemate centers on extending Affordable Care Act tax credits. Republican leaders, including Senate Majority Leader John Thune, blamed Democrats' 'far-left activist base' and rejected eliminating the 60-vote threshold. House Speaker Mike Johnson refused to bring the House back to vote on military pay, insisting Democrats pass the stopgap bill first. Democratic senators from 21 states sent a letter opposing canceled energy projects, warning of thousands of lost jobs amid an 'increasingly slowing economy.'

**Nation backs Trump manufacturing agenda despite turbulence: Poll**
A poll conducted by Tony Fabrizo for the Restoring American Dominance Coalition found that 59% of voters support the Duty Drawback program— which refunds up to 99% of certain import duties, taxes, and fees for goods exported or destroyed— compared to 17%, a 3-to-1 margin, nearly one year before the 2026 elections. The program, introduced during Trump’s first term, was partially repealed by the House’s One Big Beautiful Bill Act but restored in the Senate before being signed into law by Trump in July. The poll revealed that Republican candidates opposing Duty Drawback lost an average of 7 percentage points, with a 26-point drop among Trump voters. In a scenario where a Republican candidate supported ending the policy to raise revenue via higher taxes on exporters, the Democratic lead expanded from 3 points to 10 points, driven by a loss of support from Trump voters—from an initial 84-point lead to 58 points. The House is highly competitive in 2026 due to Speaker Mike Johnson’s narrow majority. The poll of 1,000 registered voters across 28 battleground districts (Oct. 5–7, 2025, in English and Spanish) showed that over 90% of voters believe Congress should support policies incentivizing American manufacturing and job creation, with 68% calling it very important. Among Trump voters, 89% share this view. Similarly, over 80% of voters support tax policies encouraging U.S. manufacturing, and 90% of Trump voters support foreign direct investment in American manufacturing. About 75% of independent voters and Harris voters also support such policies. The margin of error is ±3.1 points. The Restoring American Dominance Coalition, a conservative nonprofit founded by former Trump Domestic Policy Council director Joe Grogan, aims to revive American manufacturing and position the U.S. as a global leader in trade, innovation, and production.

**Taxation & Representation, Oct. 2025**
The U.S. government faces a potential shutdown on October 1, 2025, after the 'Big 4' leaders failed to reach an agreement with President Trump. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY) advocated for a broader deal including extended Advance Premium Tax Credits (eAPTCs), reversal of health care cuts from the One, Big, Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA, P.L. 119-21), and limits on the Office of Management and Budget’s (OMB) unilateral funding rescission authority. However, Senate Majority Leader John Thune (R-SD) and Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) pushed for a 'clean' stopgap bill funding the government through November 21, 2025. The Treasury Department released a contingency plan stating the IRS will remain operational for five business days during a shutdown, with all employees exempt from furlough due to multiyear appropriations from the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA, P.L. 117-169). The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) confirmed that layoffs, if implemented, would require 60 days’ notice. Meanwhile, the OBBBA accelerated the phaseout of clean energy tax credits, ending new electric vehicle (EV) tax credits as of October 1, 2025, with the alternative fuel vehicle refueling credit expiring on June 30, 2026. Investors are shifting capital toward clean energy projects that began construction before the Section 48 Investment Tax Credit (ITC) expired at the end of 2024. The Treasury and IRS released the 2025–2026 Priority Guidance Plan (PGP), prioritizing 105 projects, including OBBBA implementation, tribal tax issues, digital assets, and SECURE 2.0. The PGP also outlines the phaseout of residential clean energy credits after 2025, with wind and solar project deadlines extending through 2027, and the Clean Fuel Production Credit extended through 2029 with stricter domestic content rules. On September 22, the IRS issued proposed regulations for the 'No Tax on Tips' provision under OBBBA, allowing up to $25,000 in qualified tips to be deducted annually from 2025 to 2028, phasing out for taxpayers earning over $150,000 ($300,000 for joint filers). Eligible occupations include hospitality, food service, entertainment, personal wellness, transportation, home services, recreation, and digital content creators. The public comment period runs until October 22, 2025, with a public hearing on October 23. The Treasury also released Notices 2025-46 and 2025-49 on the Corporate Alternative Minimum Tax (CAMT), clarifying rules for domestic transactions, financially troubled firms, and consolidated groups. The IRS Office of Chief Counsel faces staffing shortages after over 350 attorneys resigned, delaying guidance on OBBBA provisions like tip income and R&D deductions. The IRS is phasing out paper tax refund checks starting September 30, 2025, under President Trump’s Executive Order, though lawmakers from Maine and New Hampshire urged a delay, citing risks to vulnerable populations and rural communities. The IRS has extended a deferred resignation offer to employees on administrative leave for the third time, with no disclosure on the number of acceptances. U.S. multinational companies are urging faster OECD Pillar Two negotiations, warning that delays could impose high compliance costs without a 'side-by-side' exception for the U.S. system. Some countries, including France, Spain, and Kenya, have maintained digital services taxes (DSTs), while India and Canada repealed theirs under U.S. pressure. The Treasury and IRS expect to release four pieces of international tax guidance by year-end, covering FDDEI, controlled foreign corporations, and foreign-earned income credits. The permanent extension of 100% bonus depreciation under OBBBA, costing $362.7 billion over 10 years, has drawn criticism from Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA), who asked the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT) to detail its beneficiaries and impacts. The Senate Finance Committee held a hearing on digital asset taxation on October 1, 2025.

**Trump Cuts $8B Clean Energy Projects in Blue States**
The Trump administration has cancelled $7.6 billion in clean energy grants for 223 projects across 16 states that voted for Democrat Kamala Harris in the 2024 presidential election, according to the U.S. Energy Department. The cuts, which include up to $1.2 billion for California’s hydrogen hub (ARCHES) and $1 billion for a Pacific Northwest hydrogen project, were justified by Energy Secretary Chris Wright as necessary to protect taxpayer dollars and ensure economic viability. Russell Vought, White House budget director, stated the cancellations targeted 'Left's climate agenda' and were politically motivated, citing that all 16 affected states supported Harris and both of their senators opposed a Republican short-term funding bill. The Energy Department reviewed grants awarded during the transition period after the 2024 election, including over a quarter awarded between Election Day and Inauguration Day. While Wright claimed the decisions were based on business criteria and not politics, Democrats and environmental groups condemned the move as punitive and shortsighted. Senator Patty Murray called it a 'blatant attempt to punish the political opposition,' and California Governor Gavin Newsom warned the cuts threaten over 200,000 jobs. The Department confirmed that terminated projects will not be restored after the government reopens. Other projects in West Virginia, Texas, and Louisiana are under review. Recipients have 30 days to appeal. The cancellations are part of a broader rollback of climate programs, including rescinding $13 billion in unspent funds from the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act. Environmental advocates, including the NRDC and Clean Air Task Force, argue the move undermines clean energy innovation, raises energy costs, and weakens U.S. competitiveness in global clean tech markets.
